AIR MAIL
TOMORROW'S MAIL TODAY
AMERICAN
AIRLINES INC.

NO SMOKING
ALLOWED
There is an ashtray in the
wall and under the arm-end
between Club Flagship seats.
If cigar or pipe smoking in-
terferes
with
your Majesty's
enjoyment of your flight, please tell the Stewardess.
She will ask such smokers to please refrain. Flag-
ship regulations permit cigar and pipe smoking
only when it is not annoying to others-the hal-
lowed "greatest good of greatest number" idea.
But cigarettes are always okay.
Another "Please": Don't smoke (1) while your
Flagship is on the ground, (2) while you are on
the ramp, (3)
while landing or taking off, (4)
while the No SmoKIng sign is on.
DONT BE
NO SHOWN
THAT EMPTY SEAT
1. A Flagship-like any ve-
hicle-is licensed to
carry a
certain maximum weight load.
Maybe, on the flight in ques-
tion, so much of that load was
devoted to war cargo that there
wasn't enough left to accommodate 21 passengers.
2. Gasoline uses up part of the allowable load.
American's flights are so scheduled that the neces-
sary amount of fuel (quantity to be used in flight,
plus a large reserve) will normally not limit the
passengers to fewer than 21. However, if winds are
less favoring than is normal, the necessary amount
of fuel is greater, and the flight may be restricted
to fewer passengers.
3. Maybe somebody was a "No Show." A No
Show is one who reserves a seat, then neither uses
it nor releases it for someone else by cancelling the
space as soon as possible
Memos
"YOUR MAJESTY
RANG?"
Whenever you want something on a Flagship, just
-please-touch the button on the wall. The answer-
ing genie-your lady-in-waiting-is the Stewardess.
She is here to serve you.
DID YOU KNOW?
Aspirin, antiseptic, alkaline fizz drinks and such are
in the Stewardess' Service Kit. Call on her for these
things-and especially if you experience any ear
distress as air pressure changes with altitude. She
can help you remedy-and suggest ways to avoid.
Form No. T-106A —Printed in U.S.A.
• ОГ
ther
rafts
YOU MAY
TAKE THE FLIGHT PACKET
This Flight Packet is yours. May-
be it will be of interest to Your
Majesty's family, your friends -
and especially to any knowledg-
able 8-or-so-year-old.
So please take it with you, if
you like,
when you leave this
Flagship at your destination.

PILLOW, PLEASE
‹YOU CAN SURESLEEP
ON CLUB FLAGSHIPS)
Are you work-worn these days? Tired
and on edge? Well, a Flagship's a fine
place for a rest cure. There's fresh air
and the drowsy hum of the motors
sweet peace for a forty-wink refresher So relax
Push the button* on the arm of your lounge chair and
lean back. Down you go to the most comfortable level.
Release the button, then, to lock the chair in position.
Now, call the Stewardess and say "Pillow"
or "Pillow
and Blanket" She will cover you up, tuck you in
wake you up on schedule.
and
ON THE HOUSE:
Complete meals-hot, or cool and
crisp as the season warrants - are
served on flights that are in the air
at mealtime. Compliments of the
Line, Your Majesty!
WHERE IS IT?
Gloves, scarf, glasses' case - got
them all? Please, before you leave
the plane, make sure you have
everything. Later, if you find you've
lost something ask the Stewardess
then, try
our Lost and Found Dept. No guarantees, of
course, but we may have it there. Inquire through any
American Airlines' office or write to Lost & Found Dept.,
American Airlines System, La Guardia Field, New York
Airport Station, New York.
WANT TO WRITE?
Catch up on old correspondence? Jot
notes or write a report? There's a com-
plete writing kit-stationery, postcards,
telegram blanks-in the rack at the front
of the cabin. Beware of your fountain
pen. Some new
ones—especially
de-
signed for modern living and with an
eye to air travel - won't commit a nui-
sance aloft. But most older pens are
ground animals. They're apt to belch
airy ink bubbles when you open them.
(At flight altitudes air pressure is lower
than where they were filled on earth.)
So play safe-have the pen full of ink-no room for air.
Open it cautiously (or let the Stewardess do it) and
replace the cap tightly when you have finished writing.
THINGS IN BOTTLES
perfumes, for instance, are subject to similar leakiness
aloft. Screw-caps are safest-and be sure they're tight.

Volando Por la Ruta de los "Flagships"
In Flight, Route of the Flagships
AMERICAN AIRLINES
¡Tan placentero que es un viaje en "Flagship"!
¡Tan tranquilo! ... que hasta el mundo y sus amar-
guras se pierden de vista.
A Flagship Trip is so refreshing! It's so calm ... and
the world and its cares are out of sight.
T-149A PRINTED IN U.S.A. 5-45
POSTCARD
2001. 015.020 d

In Flight, Route of the Flagships
AMERICAN AIRLINES
Yes! Flagships Fly down Mexico way— excellent service
to Mexico City and Monterrey.
T-149A PRINTED IN U.S.A.
POSTCARD
2001. 015.020 с

Volando Por la Ruta de los "'Flagships'
In Flight, Route of the Flagships
AMERICAN AIRLINES
¡Asómese a la ventana.... desde el cielo! Eso es gozar
de la vida; sentirse desligado de la tierra, y volar a 200
millas por hora.
Live Aloft and Like It!... in a 200 mile-an-hour "room
with a view." You feel no connection with the earth -
except as an exalted spectator.
T-152A PRINTED IN U.S.A. 5-45
POSTCARD
2001.015.020 f

Volando Por la Ruta de los "Flagships"
In Flight, Route of the Flagships
AMERICAN AIRLINES
American le Ayuda. Nada hay tan rápido cuando se
tiene prisa.
American Helps. There's no substitute for speed when
you're in a hurry.
T-151A PRINTED IN U.S.A.-
POSTCARD
2001.015. 020 g

• - - BECAUSE MORE PLANES ARE IN THE SKY
MORE EXPRESS SPACE IS AVAILABLE
Yes, the flying machines are flying back. America
has achieved fantastic goals of plane production -
so the government has been releasing additional
equipment to the airlines. This means that Air Ex- .
press has been able to find more room for shipments
that didn't fly because of war-time space restrictions.
More planes mean more flights — and that means
more cargo. While much of the equipment released
will do double duty carrying both passengers and
cargo, some of the planes will be used solely to
transport Air Mail and Air Express. And a single one
of these sky giants can carry 6,000 pounds and over.
Further, larger and more powerful carriers are on
the drawing boards of aviation's designers.
What about war cargo? Priority shipments still
come first; non-priority cargo is handled on a space-
available basis. But more space is available for all
shipments — high, low, and non-priority.
Fact is, Air Express has played an important part
in the war of production. For breakdowns and delays
come when least expected. New parts are needed
fast when a 24-hr. shift has to wait for an ailing
machine. Delivery dates get snarled up when some-
one forgets to figure the man-hour shortage. With
Air Express, you can get parts overnight, or sooner
— get orders delivered on time — meet, and beat,
the deadliest deadlines. Air Express speed has re-
duced that "longer" to a very short time indeed.
And at those lowered rates indicated below, it's a
must whenever you've something that must go
places quickly.
RATES REDUCED as Volume Increased
Not all services increased their wartime prices!
As a direct result of the great volume of Air Express
traffic created by wartime demands and the in-
creased efficiency developed to satisfy these de-
mands — Air Express rates within the U. S. were
actually reduced, in some instances as much as
12%, depending on the weight of the shipment and
the distance it moves. Shippers are saving on an
average of 10½% on pre-war Air Express costs.
Examples of Reduced Rates

AIR EXPRESS

IMPORTANT
STILL
PACK LIGHTLY -
COMPACTLY - in Small Units
and SHIP WHEN READY!
Don't pay for superfluous wrappings and trappings
but pack securely. Air Express people are trained
to handle with care and to load scientifically so you
don't have to overwrap your shipments.
Smaller packages often can make earlier planes
than bulky ones because they're easier to stow in
odd corners and this helps to provide extra space.
Break your shipments into small units when possible
- expedite your own deliveries, save time and space
for others, help cut your shipping costs.
And Ship When Ready — as early in the day as
possible. Night flights are more apt to be over-
loaded. You assure yourself of faster delivery by
shipping as soon as ready.
* AIR EXPRESS "EXTRAS"
Extra Service at no extra charge — is
still in effect. Shipments are picked up directly from
the shipper and delivered right to the consignee.
Only one waybill is necessary, and only one organi-
zation is responsible for the safe delivery.
This service is available in all cities and prin-
cipal towns within regular Railway Express Agency
vehicle limits.
Insurance is free up to $50. And just 10c extra
for each additional $100 or fraction thereof.
AIR EXPRESS
Gets there FIRST
For Service or Information, 'Phone
AIR EXPRESS DIVISION, Railway Express Agency
AD-118 (6-45) Printed in U.S.A.
